title: process
text:
What is the use of being a process ğŸ˜©

When will i get scheduled
Where am i in RAM
How can i talk to my friends
When will i get the signals
When will i get the CPU time
I cannot even talk to devices directly
I cannot even create my own child process

Only KERNEL knows

title: ğŸšSHELLğŸŒŠ
text:
login shell denotes a process created to run a shell when the user first logs in .

Bourne shell (sh) ğŸ‘¶ - Oldest and widely used

C shell (csh) - Not so portable. no backward compatible

Korn shell (ksh) ğŸŒ½ - backward compatible

Bourne again shell (bash) ğŸ‘¶ ğŸ”-reimplementation of the Bourne shell. Most widely used shell in linux

title: /etc/passwd
text:
Every user [s=24]ğŸ™ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸[/s] has a unique user name and UID 
it is in [s=24]/etc/passwd[/s]

This file also has
Group ID ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘¦â€ğŸ‘¦: the numeric group ID of the [s=24]first[/s] of the groups of which the user is a
member.

Home [s=24]ğŸ [/s] directory: the initial directory into which the user is placed after logging in.

Login [s=24]ğŸ”[/s] shell: the name of the program to be executed to interpret user commands

title: superuser ğŸ’ª
text:
user ID 0
typical login name root. [s=24]ğŸªµ[/s]

superuser can access any file in the system
send signals to any user process in the system
so on and so forth

title: groups ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘¦â€ğŸ‘¦
text:
Each group is identified by a single line in the system group file, [s=32]/etc/group[/s]

Group name: unique name of the group.

Group ID (GID): the numeric ID

User list: comma separated line of users. Primary group listed in [s=24]/etc/passwd[/s]

kernel
additional software
eg text editor ( emacs ), cli

central software that manages and allocates
computer resources (i.e., the CPU, RAM, and devices).
ğŸ“
/boot/vmlinuz

Early UNIX kernel was called unix. 
After virtual memory vmunix 

linuz z - compressed executable
task
preemptive multitasking

Multitasking - 
multiple processes (instances of running programs) simultaneously reside in memory
receive CPU use

Preemptive
rules governing which processes receive  CPU and how long determined by kernel process scheduler 
(not by processes themselves).
virtual memory management

Processes isolated from one another
and from the kernel
Only part of process kept in memory
system call API
Processes request kernel to perform tasks using kernel entry points known as system calls

eg shorthand for â€œa process can request
the kernel"
a process can create another process
a process can create a pipe
a process can write data to a file
a processcan terminate by calling exit().
process management

For a process, many things happen asynchronously. 
An executing process 
dont know when it will be scheduled.
delivery of signals and IPC events are mediated by the kernel, and can occur at any time
dont know where it is located in RAM or swap area
dont know where on the disk drive the files it accesses are being held
cannot directly communicate with another process. 
cannot itself create a new process
cannot  end its own existence. 
process cant communicate directly with IO devices

The kernel facilitates the running of all processes on the system

access to devices

CPU can access only memory marked as user space
CPU can access both user and kernel memory space.
certain operations as shut down performed in only kernel mode

when the user first logs in.

oldest of the widely used shells
Written by Steve Bourne.
standard shell for Seventh Edition UNIX

flow-control constructs resemble C programming language.
Not backward compatible with Bourne shell

GNU projects reimplementation of
the Bourne shell
widely used shell on Linux

maintain backward compatibility with Bourne shell
Incorporated features provided by C shell.
